id="about" href="#about" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>About</a></h2><div class="flex flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-store.png" alt="diagram of storage with NFT.Storage" width="1152" height="1650" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[575px]"/></div></div><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-retrieve.png" alt="diagram of retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1262" height="1260" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[630px]"/></div></div></div><div class="relative hidden xl:block"><div class="text-right"><img src="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve.png" srcSet="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve@2x.png 2x" alt="diagram of storage and retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1177" class="inline-block h-auto max-w-[84%]"/></div><div class="absolute top-0 w-full h-full flex justify-between"><div class="flex-auto max-w-[35%]"><div class="pt-32"><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p></div></div><div class="flex-auto flex items-center w-1/2 max-w-[35%] pb-16"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p></div></div></div></div></div></article><article class="bg-yellow"><div class="max-w-7xl mx-auto p-8 sm:p-16"><h2 class="chicagoflf text-center mb-16 text-black"><a id="getting-started" href="#getting-started" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Getting started is easy</a></h2><div class="grid gap-[clamp(2rem,_6vw,_6rem)] md:grid-cols-2 items-center"><img src="/images/getting-started.png" alt="getting-started" class="border-solid border-black border-2 w-full"/><ol class="list-none pl-0 mb-2"><li><div class="inline-block border border-solid border-black mb-3"><div class="inline-block relative w-full py-1 px-3 chicagoflf text-2xl text-white bg-black">Step <!-- -->1</div></div><p class="chicagoflf text-base sm:text-xl mx-auto mb-8 leading-normal"><a href="replace" class="nsnavy" tabindex="0">Create an NFT.Storage account</a> <!-- -->and start uploading your files to IPFS. id="about" href="#about" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>About</a></h2><div class="flex flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-store.png" alt="diagram of storage with NFT.Storage" width="1152" height="1650" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[575px]"/></div></div><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-retrieve.png" alt="diagram of retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1262" height="1260" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[630px]"/></div></div></div><div class="relative hidden xl:block"><div class="text-right"><img src="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve.png" srcSet="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve@2x.png 2x" alt="diagram of storage and retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1177" class="inline-block h-auto max-w-[84%]"/></div><div class="absolute top-0 w-full h-full flex justify-between"><div class="flex-auto max-w-[35%]"><div class="pt-32"><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p></div></div><div class="flex-auto flex items-center w-1/2 max-w-[35%] pb-16"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p></div></div></div></div></div></article><article class="bg-yellow"><div class="max-w-7xl mx-auto p-8 sm:p-16"><h2 class="chicagoflf text-center mb-16 text-black"><a id="getting-started" href="#getting-started" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Getting started is easy</a></h2><div class="grid gap-[clamp(2rem,_6vw,_6rem)] md:grid-cols-2 items-center"><img src="/images/getting-started.png" alt="getting-started" class="border-solid border-black border-2 w-full"/><ol class="list-none pl-0 mb-2"><li><div class="inline-block border border-solid border-black mb-3"><div class="inline-block relative w-full py-1 px-3 chicagoflf text-2xl text-white bg-black">Step <!-- -->1</div></div><p class="chicagoflf text-base sm:text-xl mx-auto mb-8 leading-normal"><a href="replace" class="nsnavy" tabindex="0">Create an NFT.Storage account</a> <!-- -->and start uploading your files to IPFS. id="about" href="#about" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>About</a></h2><div class="flex flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? id="about" href="#about" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>About</a></h2><div class="flex flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? id="about" href="#about" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>About</a></h2><div class="flex flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-store.png" alt="diagram of storage with NFT.Storage" width="1152" height="1650" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[575px]"/></div></div><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-retrieve.png" alt="diagram of retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1262" height="1260" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[630px]"/></div></div></div><div class="relative hidden xl:block"><div class="text-right"><img src="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve.png" srcSet="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve@2x.png 2x" alt="diagram of storage and retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1177" class="inline-block h-auto max-w-[84%]"/></div><div class="absolute top-0 w-full h-full flex justify-between"><div class="flex-auto max-w-[35%]"><div class="pt-32"><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). id="about" href="#about" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>About</a></h2><div class="flex flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-store.png" alt="diagram of storage with NFT.Storage" width="1152" height="1650" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[575px]"/></div></div><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-store.png" alt="diagram of storage with NFT.Storage" width="1152" height="1650" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[575px]"/></div></div><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-retrieve.png" alt="diagram of retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1262" height="1260" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[630px]"/></div></div></div><div class="relative hidden xl:block"><div class="text-right"><img src="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve.png" srcSet="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve@2x.png 2x" alt="diagram of storage and retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1177" class="inline-block h-auto max-w-[84%]"/></div><div class="absolute top-0 w-full h-full flex justify-between"><div class="flex-auto max-w-[35%]"><div class="pt-32"><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). id="about" href="#about" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>About</a></h2><div class="flex flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-store.png" alt="diagram of storage with NFT.Storage" width="1152" height="1650" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[575px]"/></div></div><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-retrieve.png" alt="diagram of retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1262" height="1260" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[630px]"/></div></div></div><div class="relative hidden xl:block"><div class="text-right"><img src="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve.png" srcSet="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve@2x.png 2x" alt="diagram of storage and retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1177" class="inline-block h-auto max-w-[84%]"/></div><div class="absolute top-0 w-full h-full flex justify-between"><div class="flex-auto max-w-[35%]"><div class="pt-32"><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p></div></div><div class="flex-auto flex items-center w-1/2 max-w-[35%] pb-16"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. rel="noreferrer">here</a>.</p></div><article class="about-section bg-nsgreen"><div class="max-w-7xl mx-auto p-8 px-6 sm:px-16"><div class="max-w-none text-left p-0"><h2 class="chicagoflf"><a id="about" href="#about" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>About</a></h2><div class="flex flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-store.png" alt="diagram of storage with NFT.Storage" width="1152" height="1650" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[575px]"/></div></div><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-retrieve.png" alt="diagram of retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1262" height="1260" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[630px]"/></div></div></div><div class="relative hidden xl:block"><div class="text-right"><img src="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve.png" srcSet="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve@2x.png 2x" alt="diagram of storage and retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1177" class="inline-block h-auto max-w-[84%]"/></div><div class="absolute top-0 w-full h-full flex justify-between"><div class="flex-auto max-w-[35%]"><div class="pt-32"><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p></div></div><div class="flex-auto flex items-center w-1/2 max-w-[35%] pb-16"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. id="about" href="#about" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>About</a></h2><div class="flex flex-col flex-1 py-4 xl:flex-row"><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal"><strong>NFT.Storage</strong> is a long-term storage service designed for <strong>off-chain</strong> NFT data (like metadata, images, and other assets) for up to 31GiB in size per individual upload. Data is<!-- --> <a href="https://nftschool.dev/concepts/content-addressing" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content addressed</a> <!-- -->using IPFS, meaning the URI pointing to a piece of data (‚Äúipfs://‚Ä¶‚Äù) is completely unique to that data (using a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/content-addressing/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">content identifier</a>, or CID). IPFS URLs and CIDs can be used in NFTs and metadata to ensure the NFT forever actually refers to the intended data (eliminating things like rug pulls, and making it trustlessly verifiable what content an NFT is associated with).</p></div><div class="w-full xl:w-1/2 xl:pr-4 mb-4"><p class="leading-normal">NFT.Storage stores many copies of uploaded data on the public IPFS network in two primary ways: in dedicated IPFS servers managed by NFT.Storage, and decentralized on<!-- --> <a href="https://filecoin.io" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin</a>. Since IPFS is a standard used by many different storage services, it&#x27;s easy to redundantly store data uploaded to NFT.Storage on any other IPFS-compatible storage solution from<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning services</a>, to your<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/install/ipfs-desktop/#windows" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">local IPFS node</a>, to other storage networks like Arweave or Storj. And as time goes on, NFT.Storage will increasingly<!-- --> <a href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->as a public good!</p></div></div></div><div class="block xl:hidden"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-store.png" alt="diagram of storage with NFT.Storage" width="1152" height="1650" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[575px]"/></div></div><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p><div class="text-center my-8"><img src="images/diagram-retrieve.png" alt="diagram of retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1262" height="1260" class="block mx-auto w-full max-w-[630px]"/></div></div></div><div class="relative hidden xl:block"><div class="text-right"><img src="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve.png" srcSet="images/diagram-store-and-retrieve@2x.png 2x" alt="diagram of storage and retrieval with NFT.Storage" width="1177" class="inline-block h-auto max-w-[84%]"/></div><div class="absolute top-0 w-full h-full flex justify-between"><div class="flex-auto max-w-[35%]"><div class="pt-32"><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="store" href="#store" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Store</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Just upload your data and you&#x27;ll receive an IPFS hash of the content (a &quot;CID,&quot; or content address) that you can use to make an IPFS URL (<code>ipfs://&lt;cid&gt;</code>). Use this IPFS URL in your NFT data to refer to <strong>off-chain</strong> data (e.g., the metadata field in your NFT, the image field in your metadata) as a pointer to the content itself, so no one can dispute what your NFT is.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Filecoin provides long-term storage for the data ensuring that even if NFT.Storage is attacked or taken down the NFT data persists! This storage is trustlessly verifiable (with on-chain, cryptographic proofs that data is stored as promised). And NFT.Storage will continue to<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://nft.storage/blog/post/2022-01-20-decentralizing-nft-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">decentralize itself</a> <!-- -->out of the picture moving forward (e.g., making perpetual storage completely smart contract-based utilizing future tools like the<!-- --> <a class="black" href="https://filecoin.io/blog/posts/introducing-the-filecoin-virtual-machine/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Filecoin Virtual Machine</a>).</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">Have additional preferences on where to store your data? Pin your data to any storage solution running a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/work-with-pinning-services/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">pinning service</a>.</p></div></div><div class="flex-auto flex items-center w-1/2 max-w-[35%] pb-16"><div><h3 class="chicagoflf"><a id="retrieve" href="#retrieve" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Retrieve</a></h3><p class="leading-normal mb-4">NFT data stored by <strong>NFT.Storage</strong> can be accessed from the decentralized IPFS network from <em>any</em> peer that has the content. CIDs reference <strong>immutable</strong> content so you can be sure the content you access is the content referenced in the NFT.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">The data can be fetched directly in the browser using<!-- --> <a href="https://brave.com/ipfs-support/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brave</a>, or via a<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/ipfs-gateway/#public-gateways" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">public IPFS gateway</a>, or by using<!-- --> <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs-desktop" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS Desktop</a> <!-- -->or the<!-- --> <a href="https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/command-line-quick-start/" class="black" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IPFS command line</a>.</p><p class="leading-normal mb-4">If fetching content using a public IPFS gateway (e.g., directly using an HTTP URL or via Brave), note that the availability and speed of retrieving the content depends on the gateway. In cases where the gateway is unable to retrieve a given CID (e.g., returns a 429 error), you can try a different gateway or running and using your own IPFS node instead.</p></div></div></div></div></div></article><article class="bg-yellow"><div class="max-w-7xl mx-auto p-8 sm:p-16"><h2 class="chicagoflf text-center mb-16 text-black"><a id="getting-started" href="#getting-started" class="group relative no-underline color-inherit"><span class="absolute -left-6 top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-all">#</span>Getting started is easy</a></h2><div class="grid gap-[clamp(2rem,_6vw,_6rem)] md:grid-cols-2 items-center"><img src="/images/getting-started.png" alt="getting-started" class="border-solid border-black border-2 w-full"/><ol class="list-none pl-0 mb-2"><li><div class="inline-block border border-solid border-black mb-3"><div class="inline-block relative w-full py-1 px-3 chicagoflf text-2xl text-white bg-black">Step <!-- -->1</div></div><p class="chicagoflf text-base sm:text-xl mx-auto mb-8 leading-normal"><a href="replace" class="nsnavy" tabindex="0">Create an NFT.Storage account</a> <!-- -->and start uploading your files to IPFS.
